Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: A Smartphone Spectrometer for Field Drug Identification
Award.AbstractNarration:
Law enforcement requires the ability to test illegal substances in the field. They need a method that is simple, rapid, accurate, definitive, safe, and affordable. However, this community has a difficult time identifying drugs in the field today, mainly due to complexities and reliability of the conventional chemistry-based method for field drug testing.

Drug field testing typically involves a police officer choosing one of many tests from a kit in order to destructively test an unknown sample in question. Many of the different tests in field kits specifically identify certain families of drugs, which make the police officer's choice of test vital to the efficiency of this process. The results of these tests are dependent on what may be a subtle color change and require the user to judge the color by eye. In addition, confusing device instructions can lead to improper testing and inaccurate results. For this reason, the current chemical test method is subject to human error and has led to false positives or negatives on many occasions. Also, hazardous chemicals in the test represent a threat to users and their equipment. The pains associated with this method give rise to the need for a new field drug test system that is superior to current methods. The proposed technology leverages smartphone and cloud technologies to providing law enforcement and crime labs with a quick, easy-to-use, dependable, safe, and relatively inexpensive testing method for testing illicit and commonly-abused substances in the field.

With this project's smartphone spectrometer technology, this I-Corps team changes the paradigm for field drug testing in the law enforcement and forensic communities. The system consists of a collection of proprietary components: a test strip, a handheld spectrometer, a smartphone app, a reference data library and a cloud-based matching application. This I-Corps team uses the prototype spectrometer and beta app to work with crime labs who have agreed to cooperate with them in establishing a beta reference library. Through prior customer interviews with law enforcement officers and crime lab analysts, the team has already received positive feedback and excitement from administrative law enforcement personnel and narcotics officers. The team is validating its product's value proposition: easy-to-use, rapid, accurate, definitive, safe, and inexpensive compared to competing technologies. At the end of this project, the team expects to solve a collection of pains associated with field drug testing within law enforcement, enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of the legal process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

We demonstrated that there is a need for better identification of controlled substances in the field.  Through interviews with officers, government officials, hardware engineers, and distributors we found that our solution meets a need and addresses the pain of using the current tests.   We confirmed that end-users need an improved solution.  The commonly implemented chemical tests have significant chemical hazards and accuracy issues. Individuals who had extensive experience with the existing field tests immediately understood the value of our solution.  Our combined smartphone app/hardware solution provides a safe and accurate way to identify controlled substances. 

Intellectual Merit

In the National Academy of Sciences’ recently published a document,  “Strengthening Forensic Science in the United States: A Path Forward,” a need for systematic research on methodologies used in forensic science was identified.  There is a large body of literature the photophysics and chemistry of the fluorescent phenomena this system uses to identify controlled substances.  As such, the fundamental science underlying the observed fluorescence has been established.  This represents a significant advance in the understanding of controlled substance screening.  By using the computing power and optics of a smartphone an accurate, robust, and cost-effective field test is realized.  

Broader Impacts

Not only does this solution meet a need of law enforcement, but also benefits the public.  By improving the accuracy and speed of field analyses there is less risk of false identifications and should produce improved confidence in identifications made with this system.  In the past, innocent people have been arrested and jailed due to false positives produced by current presumptive field tests for controlled substances. The state of the art can mistakenly identify harmless substances as controlled substances.  Falsely accused people often face legal and social problems that are directly related to the arrest.  As crime lab backlogs increase, some jurisdictions are using the results of presumptive field tests to convict not just provide probable cause.  This work supplants previous methods with a scientific, rugged, accurate, and cost effective solution that also preserves the chain of evidence. Law enforcement officials will enjoy a safer easier to use system and the public will be assured that their rights will not be abrogated by a simple false positive.
